{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3360289,"name":"Josh P","username":"BigJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bigj/{size}/93596_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T19:47:43.874Z","cooked":"

Hey all, looking for opinions and ideas as to what other teams do for selecting autos, or maybe spark discussion on the merits of different solutions. I am writing in terms of selecting a PathPlanner auto by name below, but a lot of it should pertain to any setup with multiple autos to choose between.

Problem 1: A lot of autos

Once we achieved journeyman status in making and running PathPlanner autos, our auto routine count ballooned (We wanted to be flexible, so we are talking like ~20). Amp side autos, source side autos, mid autos, starting from different points, doing note in different orders. We had a sensible naming scheme, but the best organization dashboard-side was an alphabetical list which was still very long.

Ideas:

  • Using multiple SendableChoosers, or creating some kind of tree selector widget
    • Pros: Easier to find/choose your desired auto accurately (but not necessarily quickly)
    • Cons: Adds a lot of fragility/exposure to implementation errors, between multiple/custom senders and reassembling a PathPlanner auto name to pick. May take more time to choose (see problem 2).
  • Paring down the list of autos to only a few or a single one based on the match plan.
    • Pros: Much easier to pick.
    • Cons: Susceptible to human error in mishearing what auto to leave in, pulling autos back out of “cold storage” to deploy to the RIO is annoying/time consuming
  • Drastically reducing the number of autos we offer to run for our alliance
    • Pros: Sidesteps the problem entirely
    • Cons: Annoying to deal with, having to be firm/pushy, especially in cases where we don’t have evidence of ours being “good” yet.

Problem 2: Quick-draw vs the FMS

On at least one occasion, we ended up not running an auto because we were among the final bots to connect to the field in a practice match and the match was started before the drive team could choose from the drop-down.

Ideas:

  • Training the drive team to hold thumbs-down until 100% ready
    • Pros: Will probably work
    • Cons: Would love to not have to rely on this if others have ideas
  • Setting a default PathPlanner auto name to preload/run if nothing else is selected
    • Pros: Will work
    • Cons: Hardcoding vs a PathPlanner auto name, the desired default may be different for any given match, a lot like “paring down the list” above.
  • Using a physical hardware element to choose the auto (We did this many years ago)
    • Pros: Not beholden to the FMS
    • Cons: Inflexible/prone to human error especially if we aren’t writing the names of autos on whatever the switch setup is. God help us if it was a set of dip switches to select from a library!

Would love to hear ideas and opinions from anyone, or if you have other discussion topics somewhere along these lines.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T19:47:43.874Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":255,"reads":1100,"readers_count":1099,"score":1600.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"Josh P","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-1675-ups-2024-build-thread-open-alliance/444686/41","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"FRC 1675 - UPS | 2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3360304,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T20:09:00.590Z","cooked":"
BigJ:

On at least one occasion, we ended up not running an auto because we were among the final bots to connect to the field in a practice match and the match was started before the drive team could choose from the drop-down.

We have one drive team member stand next to the robot on the field until the correct auto is selected, amongst a few other checks, and they get a thumbs up from the driver in charge of that.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T20:09:00.590Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":910,"readers_count":909,"score":317.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"Rick Lance","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":14}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":14,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360309,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T20:13:15.489Z","cooked":"

I think having multiple SendableChoosers is the way to go, each with sensible defaults.

  1. Starting Location: This is the most crucial to identify and the default should be a null value that you program to simply shoot the preload and backup on a delay. Eventually if your apriltag detection is good, you can program your disabled routine to automatically populate this value instead of using a null value.

  2. Routine: This is the actual behavior differences you want. By default you might do “Preload + 1 Close + 1 midline.” Other options could be “3 close” or “2 midline.” Or whatever else you want.

  3. Variation: This is where you specify slight variations. Like getting the midline notes in the opposite order.

It’s important that you program this robustly so that if it does fail to find the specified auto, that it still picks a sensible default.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T20:13:15.489Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":886,"readers_count":885,"score":232.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/3","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360322,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T20:26:56.839Z","cooked":"
BigJ:

On at least one occasion, we ended up not running an auto because we were among the final bots to connect to the field in a practice match and the match was started before the drive team could choose from the drop-down.

This. Happened for me during ISR DCMP. I called over the Refs and told them my computer was just really slow (and bot connected really late) before the match started, and they told the main guy (don’t really know the positions) to not start the match. However, he did not hear the Refs and the match started . Thankfully, they paused it like half a second after starting and we were given time to set up.

However, we were always consistently the last bot to connect, which really sucked bcs I usually had about less than a minute to set everything up, like controllers, auto, dashboard (etc.), which was pretty stressful. If anyone has any ideas how to make this faster or integrate software somehow, I am ready to listen.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T20:26:56.839Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":772,"readers_count":771,"score":169.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360335,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T20:35:16.949Z","cooked":"

There’s no safety rule that says you can’t power the robot before you set it down on the carpet.
It does seem counter intuitive, but honestly I’d recommend teams power their robot on the cart right before they carry it out to the field so that the radio and RIO are on and connect asap.

Not sure if we were doing that previously, but we’ll definitely enforce it more now. Thanks for the tip!

Doesn’t this cause issues with gyro calibration?

Have you seen this thread: PSA: Use A Good Ethernet Driver/Port for your Driver Station

Also, separately how’s your radio placement?

If you’re consistently last to connect by a significant
amount of time it may be worth worrying about and fixing for offseasons/next year.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T22:21:18.755Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":615,"readers_count":614,"score":128.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/psa-use-a-good-ethernet-driver-port-for-your-driver-station/460284","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"PSA: Use A Good Ethernet Driver/Port for your Driver Station","clicks":27}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":64351,"username":"GronkBaby","name":"Emil","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/8","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360483,"name":"Carlos Salazar","username":"StarbuckBarista","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starbuckbarista/{size}/186251_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T22:41:32.285Z","cooked":"

We usually have one driver focussing only on getting the correct auto selected, while the other driver and coach both do double thumbs down to make absolute sure that we aren’t left behind when starting a match.

Also, if you ever start to hear the countdown before you’re ready, here’s a tip. If you quickly unplug the ethernet cable from the driver station, FTA shouldn’t be able to start the match. Obviously, this is only a super last-minute solution, but it’s nice to know.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T22:41:32.285Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":570,"readers_count":569,"score":179.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"Carlos Salazar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":26112,"username":"rlance","name":"Rick Lance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming & Electrical Captain"},"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/9","custom_user_title":"Programming & Electrical Captain","reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360484,"name":"amber","username":"amb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/e36b37/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T22:43:29.264Z","cooked":"

You should be reseeding your gyroscope at the start of auto anyway

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T22:44:49.323Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":541,"readers_count":540,"score":108.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"amber","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54366,"username":"tecnicraze","name":"Noah Stricker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tecnicraze/{size}/235517_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54285,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"not depressed programmer"},"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/10","custom_user_title":"not depressed programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360495,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T22:49:20.632Z","cooked":"

Roborio 1 or 2?

Our roborio 1 hated connecting to the field this season. We swapped it for a 2, and experienced much better performance.

Train your drive team to hold a thumbs down on the glass window before and while they select their stuff.

I have met teams that protest for time in vague ways and get ignored.

Thumbs down, held against the glass, until everything is set up.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T22:49:20.632Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":524,"readers_count":523,"score":174.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":64351,"username":"GronkBaby","name":"Emil","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360506,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T22:54:14.571Z","cooked":"

I suppose it depends on your sensor and the implementation in code, but generally no?
The Nav X and the Pigeon IMU which are the more popular gyros, and they both have automatic drift compensation.

If you program your robot to assume its starting angle on boot up, then yes this could mess with that.
You might want to change this to calibrate in AutonEnabled instead if thats the case.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T22:54:14.571Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":505,"readers_count":504,"score":116.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462475,"topic_slug":"auto-choosing-best-practices","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54366,"username":"tecnicraze","name":"Noah Stricker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tecnicraze/{size}/235517_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/auto-choosing-best-practices/462475/12","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3360748,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-13T02:47:30.883Z","cooked":"

We use one of these, wired into a custom button board. This gives us 16 choices. In code, we have a very small RobotPeriodic routine to read these values and update a variable that is used to select the auto routine. We can also use SetOutputs (based on the value of another variable) to light LEDs. For example, we can have an LED that follows the RSL, or one that only lights when the robot has made it through certain self-tests (loaded paths, confirmed CAN device health, etc.). We normally connect quickly, and there’s time for the robot to do quite a bit while disabled, then to check in once it connects.

Unfortunately as I have found, this only works if every combination of every slot would make sense. You can’t overwrite or remove options from a SendableChooser so everything is in each one for good. I know you couldn’t remove, but I thought I might have been able to overwrite. I spent a few hours making and testing a bunch of code to dynamically filter between named autos based on dashes, only for it to all come crashing down at the end

(Work so far here: Fancy auto gen by pordonj · Pull Request #89 · frc1675/frc1675-2024 · GitHub )

BigJ:

Training the drive team to hold thumbs-down until 100% ready

100% absolutely this. As our former technician and now operator (i.e. field-side programmer), I will have our driver/coach hold a thumbs down from before the rio/radio boots and connects (before they can start the match) until I step away from the laptop and give a thumbs up.

Somewhat off-topic but here’s the mental checklist I used setting up the DS before a match:

  • Thumbs-down
  • Check that joysticks are registering on the correct ports and that all axes read zero with controls centered
  • Wait for robot to connect
  • Check that odometry looks like approximately where the robot actually is on the field (yes we ran AdvantageScope on the DS laptop during matches because we didn’t have real data logging)
  • Check that the robot has the correct alliance from FMS
  • Set the auto**
  • Enable debug output from the robot (disabled by default because we thought it was causing memory leaks; it wasn’t and this should go away but we never got around to it)
  • Clear the console and verify that no new error messages are appearing
  • Thumbs up and step behind the line

This was sometimes annoyingly slow but we never had any failures related to improper setup.

**We’re using a SendableChooser with a submit button. We had choosers do weird things in 2022 to the point that I wouldn’t be confident what was selected, so in addition to the auto chooser we have a “set auto” button and a “selected auto” text box. Pressing set auto reads the chooser and sets the auto command, then gets the name of the auto command and writes it to the text box, giving confirmation that the correct auto is selected.
